title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: oneMeanTest package provides tools performing one-sample t-test population mean variance unknown, along descriptive statistics, assumption checks, bootstrap-based inference, power analysis, informative plots. vignette shows complete analysis workflow using simulated data mimics real application.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: library(oneMeanTest) set.seed(123)

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: Suppose measure numeric outcome (e.g., exam scores, weights, waiting times) n=30n = 30 individuals, want test whether population mean equals hypothesized value Œº0=5\mu_0 = 5. simulate dataset: x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2) head(x) length(x) can replace simulated data dataset using package practice.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: running hypothesis test, examine basic descriptive statistics. ds <- descriptive_stats(x, digits = NULL) ds output includes sample size, mean, median, standard deviation, standard error, variance, range, quartiles, IQR.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: now perform one-sample t-test H0:Œº=5vs.Ha:Œº‚â†5. H_0: \mu = 5 \quad \text{vs.} \quad H_a: \mu \neq 5. res <- one_mean_test( x, mu0 = 5, alternative = ‚Äútwo.sided‚Äù, alpha = 0.05, conf.level = 0.95, check_assumptions = TRUE ) res printed result shows: t statistic degrees freedom p-value confidence interval mean sample mean decision reject fail reject H0H_0 plain-language interpretation.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: one-sample t-test assumes data approximately normally distributed (sample size large enough central limit theorem apply). check_assumptions() function, called inside one_mean_test() check_assumptions = TRUE, provides basic assessment: assump <- check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = FALSE) assump Interpret results decide whether normality assumption reasonable.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: plot() method oneMeanTest objects provides several useful visualizations. First, t-distribution observed t statistic critical values: plot(res, = ‚Äút‚Äù) Next, confidence interval plot mean: plot(res, = ‚Äúci‚Äù) store raw data result object, can also draw histogram, boxplot, normal Q-Q plot: attr(res, ‚Äúdata‚Äù) <- x plot(res, = ‚Äúhist‚Äù) plot(res, = ‚Äúbox‚Äù) plot(res, = ‚Äúqq‚Äù) plots can used directly screenshots presentation.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: bootstrap_ttest() function implements simple non-parametric bootstrap procedure one-sample mean. boot_res <- bootstrap_ttest( x, mu0 = 5, nboot = 500, conf.level = 0.95, alternative = ‚Äútwo.sided‚Äù, seed = 123 ) boot_res can compare bootstrap confidence interval p-value classical t-test results part discussion.

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: Finally, power_analysis_one_mean() wraps stats::power.t.test() one-sample t-tests. example, compute power detecting true difference 1 unit n=30n = 30, sd=2sd = 2, Œ±=0.05\alpha = 0.05: p_res <- power_analysis_one_mean( n = 30, delta = 1, sd = 2, sig.level = 0.05, power = NULL, alternative = ‚Äútwo.sided‚Äù ) p_res find required sample size 80% power: n_res <- power_analysis_one_mean( n = NULL, delta = 1, sd = 2, sig.level = 0.05, power = 0.8, alternative = ‚Äútwo.sided‚Äù ) n_res

title: Introduction to oneMeanTest
text: vignette, : simulated numeric dataset; computed descriptive statistics; performed one-sample t-test using one_mean_test(); checked assumptions, created informative plots, compared bootstrap-based inference; explored power analysis using power_analysis_one_mean(). can adapt workflow data analyze single population mean unknown variance create materials STAT 181 presentation.

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: ‚úÖ One-sample t-test complete statistical inference ‚úÖ Custom implementations statistical functions (reliance built-t-test) ‚úÖ Bootstrap inference robust non-parametric alternatives ‚úÖ Power analysis sample size effect size calculations ‚úÖ Assumption checking Shapiro-Wilk test outlier detection ‚úÖ Rich visualizations including distributions, Q-Q plots, confidence intervals ‚úÖ Multiple output formats (console, markdown, LaTeX reports)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: üéØ 360+ comprehensive tests 85%+ code coverage üìä 4-decimal accuracy validated R‚Äôs built-functions üî¨ Production-ready full documentation vignettes üöÄ Zero dependencies beyond base R packages (stats, graphics)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: # Install from GitHub if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("devtools") } devtools::install_github("KingSSIBAL/oneMeanTest")

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: library(oneMeanTest)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: Output:
code: # Generate sample data set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 100, sd = 15)  # Perform t-test result <- one_mean_test(   x = x,   mu0 = 100,              # Null hypothesis value   alternative = "two.sided",   alpha = 0.05,   conf.level = 0.95,   check_assumptions = TRUE )  # View results print(result) ======================================== ONE-SAMPLE T-TEST RESULTS ========================================  Sample: x n = 30, mean = 101.5847, sd = 14.5782  H‚ÇÄ: Œº = 100 H‚Çê: Œº ‚â† 100 Œ± = 0.05  TEST STATISTICS t = 0.5954, df = 29 p-value = 0.5565 Critical values: -2.0452, 2.0452  95% CONFIDENCE INTERVAL [96.1402, 107.0292]  DECISION: fail to reject H‚ÇÄ  INTERPRETATION: At the 0.05 significance level, there is insufficient evidence to conclude that the population mean is different from 100.

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: descriptive_stats(x)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: non-parametric inference normality assumptions violated:
code: # Bootstrap t-test (1000 resamples) bootstrap_result <- bootstrap_ttest(   x = x,   mu0 = 100,   nboot = 1000,   conf.level = 0.95,   seed = 123 )  print(bootstrap_result) plot(bootstrap_result)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: Calculate required sample size, power, detectable effect size:
code: # Calculate power for given sample size and effect power_t_test(n = 30, delta = 5, sd = 15, alpha = 0.05) # [1] 0.3520  # Calculate required sample size for 80% power sample_size_t_test(power = 0.80, delta = 5, sd = 15, alpha = 0.05) # [1] 143  # Calculate detectable effect size effect_size_t_test(n = 30, power = 0.80, sd = 15, alpha = 0.05) # [1] 8.19  # Visualize power curve plot_power_curve(delta = 5, sd = 15, alpha = 0.05)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: Output:
code: # Check assumptions assumptions <- check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = TRUE)  # Interpret assumptions interpret_assumptions(assumptions) ‚úì Normality: Shapiro-Wilk test p-value = 0.3245 (data appear normal) ‚úì Outliers: 0 potential outliers detected ‚úì Sample size: n = 30 (adequate for t-test)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: # Distribution plot plot(result, type = "distribution")  # Confidence interval plot plot(result, type = "ci")  # Diagnostic plots (Q-Q plot + boxplot) plot(result, type = "diagnostic")  # All plots at once plot(result, type = "all")  # Individual diagnostic plots plot_qq(x)        # Q-Q plot for normality plot_histogram(x) # Histogram with normal curve plot_boxplot(x)   # Boxplot with outliers highlighted

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: # Generate formatted report report <- format_ttest_report(result) cat(report)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: # Save as text file report(result, file = "ttest_report.txt")  # Save as Markdown report(result, format = "markdown", file = "ttest_report.md")  # Save as LaTeX report(result, format = "latex", file = "ttest_report.tex")

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
code: # Interpret p-value strength interpret_p_value(0.03) # "moderate evidence against the null hypothesis"  # Interpret effect size (Cohen's d) d <- cohens_d(x, mu0 = 100) interpret_effect_size(d) # "small effect size"  # Interpret confidence interval interpret_ci(result$conf.int, conf_level = 0.95, mu0 = 100)

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: core statistical functions custom-implemented educational purposes: .custom_quantile() - Quantile calculation (Type 7) .custom_pt() / .custom_qt() - t-distribution functions .custom_pnorm() / .custom_qnorm() - Normal distribution functions .incomplete_beta() - Beta function t-distribution match R‚Äôs built-functions 4 decimal places (validated 360+ tests).

title: One-Sample T-Test for Population Mean with Unknown Variance
text: Use oneMeanTest : ‚úÖ one numeric sample (independent observations) ‚úÖ want test hypothesis single population mean ‚úÖ need assumption checking diagnostic plots ‚úÖ want bootstrap alternatives robustness ‚úÖ need power analysis study design ‚úÖ want comprehensive, publication-ready reports ‚úÖ ‚Äôre learning statistical computing concepts Alternative approaches: Large samples (n > 30): Central Limit Theorem applies, normality less critical Non-normal data: Use bootstrap_ttest() non-parametric inference Paired data: Use paired t-test (package) Two independent samples: Use two-sample t-test (package)

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test ‚Äî bootstrap_ttest
text: Perform simple non-parametric bootstrap procedure one-sample t-test population mean unknown variance.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test ‚Äî bootstrap_ttest
code: bootstrap_ttest(   x,   mu0 = 0,   nboot = 1000,   conf.level = 0.95,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   seed = NULL )

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test ‚Äî bootstrap_ttest
text: x Numeric vector observations. mu0 Hypothesized population mean null hypothesis. nboot Number bootstrap resamples (integer, usually least 100). conf.level Confidence level bootstrap confidence interval. alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis, one "two.sided", "less", "greater". seed Optional integer seed reproducibility.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test ‚Äî bootstrap_ttest
text: list class "oneMeanTest_bootstrap" components: t.obs Observed t-statistic. t.boot Numeric vector bootstrap t-statistics. mean.obs Observed sample mean. mean.boot Numeric vector bootstrap means. conf.int Bootstrap percentile confidence interval mean (numeric vector length 2 attribute conf.level). p.value Bootstrap p-value. nboot Number bootstrap resamples. mu0 Hypothesized mean. alternative Alternative hypothesis used. call matched function call.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test ‚Äî bootstrap_ttest
text: function resamples observed data replacement, computes t-statistic bootstrap sample, uses empirical distribution statistics obtain bootstrap p-value percentile confidence interval mean. useful illustrating resampling-based inference comparing classical t-test results bootstrap results.

title: Bootstrap one-sample t-test ‚Äî bootstrap_ttest
code: set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2)  boot_res <- bootstrap_ttest(   x,   mu0 = 5,   nboot = 500,   conf.level = 0.95,   alternative = "two.sided",   seed = 123 ) boot_res #> Bootstrap one-sample t-test #>  #> Call: #> bootstrap_ttest(x = x, mu0 = 5, nboot = 500, conf.level = 0.95,  #>     alternative = "two.sided", seed = 123) #>  #> Observed t-statistic: -0.2630 #> Bootstrap p-value  : 0.826 #> 95.0000% bootstrap CI for the mean: #>   [4.1933, 5.5355] #> Number of resamples: 500

what: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
text: Check normality outliers numeric sample, typically required one-sample t-test population mean unknown variance.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
code: check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = TRUE)

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
text: x numeric vector observations. alpha Significance level Shapiro‚ÄìWilk normality test. verbose Logical; TRUE, prints short textual summary results console.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
text: list class "oneMeanTest_assumptions" components: shapiro List W statistic, p-value, alpha, logical flag normal indicating normality acceptable (NA test run). outliers Numeric vector detected outliers (possibly empty). n Sample size removing NA values. normal Logical flag indicating normality acceptable (TRUE / FALSE), FALSE Shapiro‚ÄìWilk test rejects chosen alpha. message Textual summary diagnostics.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
text: function performs Shapiro‚ÄìWilk normality test (sample size 3 5000) detects outliers using 1.5*IQR rule. used inside one_mean_test check_assumptions = TRUE.

title: Assumption checks for one-sample t-test ‚Äî check_assumptions
code: set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2)  # Verbose output check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = TRUE) #> Normality appears acceptable based on the Shapiro-Wilk test. No outliers detected by the 1.5*IQR rule.  #> $shapiro #> $shapiro$W #> [1] 0.9789351 #>  #> $shapiro$p.value #> [1] 0.7965839 #>  #> $shapiro$alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $shapiro$normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #>  #> $outliers #> numeric(0) #>  #> $n #> [1] 30 #>  #> $normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $message #> [1] "Normality appears acceptable based on the Shapiro-Wilk test. No outliers detected by the 1.5*IQR rule." #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "oneMeanTest_assumptions"  # Silent output (used internally by one_mean_test) a_res <- check_assumptions(x, alpha = 0.05, verbose = FALSE) a_res #> $shapiro #> $shapiro$W #> [1] 0.9789351 #>  #> $shapiro$p.value #> [1] 0.7965839 #>  #> $shapiro$alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $shapiro$normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #>  #> $outliers #> numeric(0) #>  #> $n #> [1] 30 #>  #> $normal #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $message #> [1] "Normality appears acceptable based on the Shapiro-Wilk test. No outliers detected by the 1.5*IQR rule." #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "oneMeanTest_assumptions"

what: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
text: Compute basic descriptive statistics numeric vector, including sample size, mean, median, standard deviation, variance, standard error, quartiles, range, interquartile range (IQR).

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
code: descriptive_stats(x, digits = 4)

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
text: x numeric vector observations. digits Optional integer; number digits round printed output. NULL, rounding applied.

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
text: data frame one row summary statistics: n: sample size (number non-missing observations). mean: sample mean. median: sample median. sd: sample standard deviation. variance: sample variance. se: standard error mean. min, q1, q3, max: minimum, first quartile, third quartile, maximum. iqr: interquartile range (q3 - q1).

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
text: function intended numeric data measurements scores, typically type data used one-sample t-test.

title: Descriptive statistics for a numeric sample ‚Äî descriptive_stats
code: x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) descriptive_stats(x) #>  n mean median     sd variance     se min q1 q3 max iqr #>  5    3      3 1.5811      2.5 0.7071   1  2  4   5   2  # Without rounding descriptive_stats(x, digits = NULL) #>  n mean median       sd variance        se min q1 q3 max iqr #>  5    3      3 1.581139      2.5 0.7071068   1  2  4   5   2

what: Calculate detectable effect size for given power ‚Äî effect_size_t_test
title: Calculate detectable effect size for given power ‚Äî effect_size_t_test
text: Determines effect size can detected specified power

title: Calculate detectable effect size for given power ‚Äî effect_size_t_test
code: effect_size_t_test(   n,   power = 0.8,   sd,   alpha = 0.05,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater") )

title: Calculate detectable effect size for given power ‚Äî effect_size_t_test
text: n Sample size power Desired power (default 0.80) sd Standard deviation alpha Significance level (default 0.05) alternative Alternative hypothesis

title: Calculate detectable effect size for given power ‚Äî effect_size_t_test
text: Detectable effect size (original units)

title: Calculate detectable effect size for given power ‚Äî effect_size_t_test
code: # Effect size detectable with 80% power and n=30 effect_size_t_test(n = 30, power = 0.80, sd = 1) #> [1] 0.5270605

title: Format T-test Report ‚Äî format_ttest_report

title: oneMeanTest: One-sample t-test package ‚Äî oneMeanTest
text: oneMeanTest package provides functions perform one-sample t-test population mean population variance unknown, along assumption checks, descriptive statistics, basic plotting utilities educational use.

title: oneMeanTest: One-sample t-test package ‚Äî oneMeanTest
text: Maintainer: Name .email@example.com

what: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) ‚Äî one_mean_test
title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) ‚Äî one_mean_test
text: Perform one-sample t-test population mean population variance unknown, using Student's t-distribution. function returns usual test statistic, p-value, confidence interval, plain-language interpretation, can optionally run assumption checks.

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) ‚Äî one_mean_test
code: one_mean_test(   x,   mu0 = 0,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   alpha = 0.05,   conf.level = 0.95,   check_assumptions = TRUE )

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) ‚Äî one_mean_test
text: x numeric vector observations. mu0 hypothesized population mean null hypothesis. alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis, one "two.sided", "less", "greater". alpha Significance level used hypothesis decision. conf.level Confidence level confidence interval. check_assumptions Logical; TRUE, performs assumption checks via check_assumptions stores result returned object.

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) ‚Äî one_mean_test
text: object class "oneMeanTest" containing: statistic Named numeric vector t statistic. parameter Named numeric vector degrees freedom. p.value P-value test. conf.int Numeric vector confidence interval mean, attribute conf.level. estimate Named numeric vector sample mean. null.value Named numeric vector hypothesized mean (mu0). alternative Character string alternative hypothesis. t.critical Named vector critical value(s) test. method Description method used. data.name Character string name data vector. sample.stats List n, mean, sd, se. alpha Significance level used. assumptions Result check_assumptions() NULL. decision Character string: "reject H0" "fail reject H0". interpretation Plain-language interpretation result.

title: One-sample t-test for a population mean (unknown variance) ‚Äî one_mean_test
